Question: Electricity costs $0.27 per kWh.How much does 20 kWh cost?

Subject: MG2
Question: Toby's mobile phone plan costs $20 per month, plus the cost of all calls. Calls are charged at the rate of 70 cents per 30 seconds, or part thereof. There is also a call connection fee of 50c per call.Here is a record of all his calls in July.
Q1: How much is Toby's mobile phone bill for July?

Subject: MG2
Question: A farmer needed to estimate the number of goats on his property. He tagged 80 of his goats. Later, he collected a random sample of 45 goats and found that 16 of these had tags.Estimate the number of goats the farmer has on his property.
S1: Let N be the number of goats.16/45 = 80/NN = (80*45)/16= 225- The estimated number of goats the farmer has on his property is 225.

Subject: MG2
Question: A sewer pipe needs to be placed into the ground so that it has a 2 degrees angle of depression. The length of the pipe is 15 000 mm.
Q1: How much deeper should one end of the pipe be compared to the other end? Answer to the nearest mm.
S1: Let x be the required depth.sin2 = x/15000= 15000 sin2= 523.4...= 523 mm (to the nearest mm)

Subject: MG2
Question: Sam purchased 500 company shares at $3.20 per share. Brokerage fees were 1.5% of the purchase price.Sam is paid a dividend of 26 cents per share, then immediately sells the shares for $4.80 each.If he pays no further brokerage fees, what is Sam's total profit?
S1: Share cost = 500 - 3.20= $1600Brokerage = 1.5% - 1600= $24Total cost = $1624Share selling price = 500 - 4.80= $2400Dividend = 0.26 - 500= $130Total proceeds = 2400 + 130= $2530Total profit = 2530 - 1624= $906

Subject: MG2
Question: The area chart shows the number of goals scored by three hockey teams, A, Band C, in the first 4 rounds.
Q1: How many goals were scored by team C in round 1?
Q2: In which round did all three teams score the same number of goals?

Subject: MG2
Question: Rachel bought a motorcycle advertised for $7990. She paid a $500 deposit and took out a flat-rate loan to repay the balance. Simple interest was charged at a rate of 7% per annum on the amount borrowed. She repaid the loan over 2 years, making equal weekly repayments.Calculate the weekly repayment.

Subject: MG2
Question: Jamal surveyed eight households in his street. He asked them how many kilolitres (kL) of water they used in the last year. Here are the results. 220, 105, 101, 450, 37, 338, 151, 205
Q1: Calculate the mean of this set of data.
Q2: What is the standard deviation of this set of data, correct to one decimal place?

Subject: MG2
Question: How many 20 megabyte files can fit on a 3 terabyte external hard disc?
S1: 3 terabytes = 3 - 2^40 bytes20 megabytes = 20 - 2^20 bytesNumber of files =(3 - 2^40)/(20 - 2^20)=157 286.4

Subject: MG2
Question: A table of future value interest factors for an annuity of $1 is shown. An annuity involves contributions of $12 000 per annum for 5 years. Theinterest rate is 4% per annum, compounded annually.
Q1: Calculate the future value of this annuity.
Q2: Calculate the interest earned on this annuity.

Subject: MG2
Question: Island A and island B are both on the equator. Island B is west of island A. The longitude of island A is 5\(^{\circ}\)E and the angle at the centre of Earth (O), between A and B, is 30\(^{\circ}\).
Q1: What is the longitude of island B? Answer in the format XXdegreesY (eg 10degreesS)
Q2: What time is it on island B when it is 10 am on island A?
S2: Time difference = 15= 2 hoursTime on island B = 10 am - 2 hours= 8 am
Q3: How long will the ship take to arrive at island B? Give your answer in days and hours to the nearest hour.
S3: Distance = 30/360 * 2pi * 6400= 3351.0..kmTime = 3351.0../40 hours= 83.7..hours= 83.7../ 24 days= 3.490658504 days= 3 days + (0.490658504 x 24) hours= 3 days + 11.7..hours= 3 days 12 hours (nearest hour)

Subject: MG2
Question: Rhys is drinking low alcohol beer at a party over a five-hour period. He reads on the label of the low alcohol beer bottle that it is equivalent to 0.8 of a standard drink.Rhys weighs 90 kg.What is the maximum number of complete bottles of the low alcohol beer he can drink to remain under a Blood Alcohol Content (BAC) of 0.05?

Subject: MG2
Question: Temperature can be measured in degrees Celsius (C) or degrees Fahrenheit (F). The two temperature scales are related by the equation shown.$$F={9C \over 5}+32$$
Q1: Calculate the temperature in degrees Fahrenheit when it is -20 degrees Celsius.
Q2: Solve the following equations simultaneously, using either the substitution method or the elimination method. $$F={9C \over 5}+32 \\ F=C$$

Subject: MG2
Question: Five people are in a team. Two of them are selected at random to attend a competition.
Q1: How many different groups of two can be selected?
Q2: If Mary is one of the five people in the team, what is the probability that she is selected to attend the competition?
S2: Four of the ten possible groups include Mary (ie a group including Mary and one of the other 4 team members).The probability = 4/10  = 0.4

Subject: MG2
Question: Michelle borrows $100 000. The interest rate charged is 12% per annum compounded monthly. The monthly payment is $1029 and the first repayment is made after one month.What is the amount outstanding immediately after the SECOND monthly repayment is made?
S1: Amount owing after first month = 100000*(1+0.12/12)-1029 = 99971Amount owing after second month = 99971*(1+0.12/12)-1029 = 99941.71

Subject: MG2
Question: Make y the subject of the equation $$x=\sqrt{yp-1}$$

Subject: MG2
Question: A movie theatre has 200 seats. Each ticket currently costs $8. The theatre owners are currently selling all 200 tickets for each session. They decide to increase the price of tickets to see if they can increase the income earned from each movie session.It is assumed that for each one dollar increase in ticket price, there will be 10 fewer tickets sold.A graph showing the relationship between an increase in ticket price and the income is shown below.
Q1: What ticket price should be charged to maximise the income from a movie session?
S1: From the graph, the income is maximised when the increase in ticket price is $6.- the ticket price should be $8 + $6 = $14
Q2: What is the number of tickets sold when the income is maximised?
Q3: The cost to the theatre owners of running each session is $500 plus $2 per ticket sold. Calculate the profit earned by the theatre owners when the income earned from a session is maximised.

Subject: MG2
Question: A new 200-metre long dam is to be built.The plan for the new dam shows evenly spaced cross-sectional areas.
Q1: Using TWO applications of Simpson's rule, calculate the volume of the dam in m\(^{3}\).
Q2: It is known that the catchment area for this dam is 2 km\(^{2}\).Calculate how much rainfall is needed, to the nearest mm, to fill the dam.

Subject: MG2
Question: Sabrina's taxable income is $86 725 in a particular year. The table below is used to calculate her tax payable. In addition, she pays the Medicare levy, which is 2% of her taxable income. Calculate Sabrina's net income in that year.

Subject: MG2
Question: A group of Year 12 students was surveyed. The students were asked whether they live in the city or the country. They were also asked if they have ever waterskied.The results are recorded in the table.
Q1: A person is selected at random from the group surveyed. Calculate the probability that the person lives in the city and has never waterskied (to the nearest percentage).
Q2: A newspaper article claimed that Year 12 students who live in the country are more likely to have waterskied than those who live in the city.Is this true, based on the survey results?
S2: Country students who have water skied: 70/ 870- 100 = 8.04..%150 City students who have water skied: 150/ 2650 - 100 = 5.66..%The claim in the newspaper article is true.

Subject: MG2
Question: All the students in a class of 30 did a test.The marks, out of 10, are shown in the dot plot.
Q1: Find the median test mark.
Q2: The mean test mark is 5.4 . The standard deviation of the test marks is 4.22.Using the dot plot, calculate the percentage of the marks which lie within one standard deviation of the mean.
S2: Mean minus standard deviation = 5.4 - 4.22 = 1.18Mean plus standard deviation = 5.4 + 4.22 = 9.62 Percentage of marks between 1.18 and 9.62 = (2 + 2 + 2 + 1 + 6)/30 = 43.3% (1 decimal place)
Q3: A student states that for any data set, 68% of the scores should lie within one standard deviation of the mean.With reference to the dot plot, explain why the student's statement is NOT relevant in this context.
S3: The dot plot does not show a normally distributed data set, so the statement is not relevant.

Subject: MG2
Question: A set of data has a lower quartile (QL) of 10 and an upper quartile (QU) of 16. What is the maximum possible range for this set of data if there are no outliers?
S1: Interquartile range (IQR) = QU - QL= 16 - 10= 6 Lower bound = QL - 1.5 - IQR= 10 - 1.5 - 6= 1 Upper bound = QU + 1.5 - IQR= 16 + 1.5 - 6= 25- Range = 25 - 1= 24

Subject: MG2
Question: The cost of a jewellery box varies directly with the cube of its height. A jewellery box with a height of 10 cm costs $50.Calculate the cost of a jewellery box with a height of 12 cm.
S1: Let C be the cost of the jewellery box.Let h be the height of the jewellery box.C = kh^3 where k is a constant.50 = k * 10^3k = 0.05When h=12cost, C = 0.05 * 12^3= $86.40

Subject: MG2
Question: The diagram shows the location of three schools. School A is 5 km due north of school B, school C is 13 km from school B and ABC is 135\(^{\circ}\).
Q1: Calculate the shortest distance from school A to school C, to the nearest kilometre.
Q2: Determine the bearing of school C from school A, to the nearest degree.
S2: sinA/13 = sin135/17sinA = 13sin135/17=0.5407A = 32.7..=33The bearing of school C from chool A is 180+33=213

Subject: MG2
Question: In an investigation, students used different numbers of identical small solar panels to power model cars. The cars were then tested and their speed measured in km/h. The results are summarised in the table.The equation of the least-squares line of best fit, relating the speed and the number of solar panels, has been calculated to be y = 2.125x + 2.0375.
Q1: What would be the speed of a car powered by 5 solar panels, based on this equation?
Q2: Calculate the correlation coefficient, r, between the number of solar panels and the speed of a car.
S2: gradient = r * (standard deviation of y scores /standard deviation of x scores)2.125 = r - 2 / 0.8r = 0.85

Subject: MG2
Question: A solid is made up of a sphere sitting partially inside a cone. The sphere, centre O, has a radius of 4 cm and sits 2 cm inside the cone. The solid has a total height of 15 cm. The solid and its cross-section are shown. What is the volume of the cone, correct to the nearest cm\(^{3}\)?
S1: Radius of cone, r = sqrt(4^2 - 2^2)= sqrt(12) cmHeight of cone, h = 15 - (4 + 2)= 9 cmVolume of cone, V =1/3*pi*r^2*h=1/3 * pi * (sqrt(12)^2 * 9= 113.09..= 113 cm3 (to nearest cm3)

Question: Calculate the surface area of a sphere with a radius of 5 cm, correct to the nearest whole number.

Subject: MG2
Question: Peta's car uses fuel at the rate of 5.9 L /100 km for country driving and7.3 L /100 km for city driving. On a trip, she drives 170 km in the country and 25 km in the city.Calculate the amount of fuel she used on this trip.
S1: Country driving: 170/100 * 5.9 = 10.03LCity driving: 25/100 * 7.3 = 1.825LTotal fueld used = 10.03 + 1.825= 11.855L

Question: The field diagram shows a block of land \(ABCD\) that has been surveyed. All measurements are in metres.
Q1: Calculate the length of \(AB\), correct to the nearest metre.

Question: Theo is completing his tax return. He has a gross salary of $82521 and income from a rental property totalling $10920. He is claiming $13420 in allowable deductions.
Q1: Determine Theo's taxable income.
Q2: Using the tax table below, calculate Theo's tax payable.
Q3: In addition to the above tax, Theo must also pay a Medicare levy of $1600.42.Theo has already paid $20525 as Pay As You Go (PAYG) tax.Should Theo receive a tax refund or will he owe more tax? Justify your answer with calculations.

Subject: MG2
Question: Alice intends to buy a car and insure it.Briefly describe what each of these types of insurance covers:\(\bullet\) Compulsory third-party insurance (CTP)\(\bullet\) Non-compulsory third-party property insurance.
A1: If Alice is responsible for a car accident, then Compulsory Third Party Insurance covers injury to people, while Third Party Property Insurance covers damage to other people's property.

Subject: MG2
Question: A small population consists of three students of heights 153 cm, 168 cm and 174 cm. Samples of varying sizes can be taken from this population.What is the mean of the mean heights of all the possible samples? Justify your answer.
A1: 165. The mean of all possible sample means is equal to the population mean

Subject: MG2
Question: The heights of 400 students were measured. The results are displayed in thiscumulative frequency polygon.
Q1: Use the polygon to estimate the interquartile range.

Question: Marge borrowed $19000 to buy a used car. Interest on the loan was charged at 4.8% pa at the end of each month. She made a repayment of $436 at the end of every month. The table below sets out her monthly repayment schedule for the first four months of the loan.
Q1: Some values in the table are missing. Write down the values for A and B.
Q2: Calculate the value of \(X\).
Q3: Marge repaid this loan over four years.What is the total amount that Marge repaid?

Question: Melbourne is located at (38\(^{\circ}\)S, 145\(^{\circ}\)E) and Dubai is located at (24\(^{\circ}\)N, 55\(^{\circ}\)E).
Q1: Calculate the difference in longitude between Melbourne and Dubai.
Q2: Show that the time difference between Melbourne and Dubai is 6 hours.
Q3: A plane leaves Melbourne on Friday at 11.30 pm. The flight time to Dubai is 15 hours.What will be the time and the day in Dubai when the plane is due to land?

Subject: MG2
Question: Jacob has a large jar of silver coins. He adds 20 gold coins into the jar. He then seals the jar and shakes it to ensure that the gold coins are mixed in thoroughly with the silver coins. Jacob then opens the jar and takes a handful of coins. In his hand he has 33 silver coins and 4 gold coins.
Q1: Based on Jacob's handful, if a coin is selected at random from the jar, what is the probability that it is a gold coin?
Q2: Jacob returns the handful of coins to the jar. Estimate the total number of coins in the jar.

Subject: MG2
Question: The cost of buying a new heater is $990. It uses energy according to thefollowing energy label.
Q1: Energy is charged at the rate of $0.35/ kWh.How much will it cost in total to purchase and then run this heater for five years?

Subject: MG2
Question: A cricket team is about to play two matches. The probability of the team having a win, a loss or a draw is 0.7, 0.1 and 0.2 respectively in each match. The possible results in the two matches are displayed in the probability tree diagram.
Q1: What is the probability of the team having a win and a draw, in any order?
Q2: Paul claims that 1.4 is the probability of the team winning both matches.Give one reason why this is NOT correct.
A2: Paul is not correct because the probability of an event occurring cannot be greater than 1.

Subject: MG2
Question: The table gives the contribution per period for an annuity with a future value of $1 at different interest rates and different periods of time.
Q1: Margaret needs to save $75000 over 6 years for a deposit on a new apartment. She makes regular quarterly contributions into an investment account whichpays interest at 3% pa.How much will Margaret need to contribute each quarter to reach her savingsgoal?

Subject: MG2
Question: A company makes large marshmallows. They are in the shape of a cylinder with diameter 5 cm and height 3 cm, as shown in the diagram.
Q1: Find the volume of one of these large marshmallows, correct to one decimal place.
Q2: A cake is to be made by stacking 24 of these large marshmallows and filling the gaps between them with chocolate. The diagrams show the cake and its top view. The shading shows the gaps to be filled with chocolate.What volume of chocolate will be required? Give your answer correctto the nearest whole number.

Subject: MG2
Question: Two unbiased coins are tossed.
Q1: What is the probability that one coin shows heads and the other shows tails?
Q2: A game is played in which one player tosses the two coins. The rules are as follows:\(\bullet\) If both coins show heads, the player wins $40\(\bullet\) If both coins show tails, the player wins $20\(\bullet\) If one coin shows heads and the other shows tails, the player loses $30What is the financial expectation of this game?

Subject: MG2
Question: The mass \(M\) kg of a baby pig at age \(x\) days is given by \(M=A(1.1)^{x}\) where \(A\) is a constant. The graph of this equation is shown.
Q1: What is the value of \(A\)?
Q2: What is the daily growth rate of the pig's mass? Write your answer as a percentage.

Subject: MG2
Question: The ages of members of a dance class are shown in the back-to-backstem-and-leaf plot.
Q1: Pat claims that the women who attend the dance class are generally older than the men. Is Pat correct?Justify your answer by referring to the median and skewness of the two sets of data.
A1: Pat is correct since the women's median age (55) is higher than the men's median age (45) and there are more women in the older age group (negatively skewed).

Subject: MG2
Question: Five students sat both a Physics and a Chemistry exam. Their results are shown in the table. The mean and standard deviation of each exam are also shown.The correlation coefficient for this data set is approximately 0.9.
Q1: Verify the value of the correlation coefficient, using your calculator, and give your value correct to three decimal places.
Q2: By using the appropriate formulae from the Formulae and Data Sheet, and the given information, determine the equation of the least-squares line of best fit.

Subject: MG2
Question: The graph shows the life expectancy of people born between 1900 and 2000.
Q1: According to the graph, what is the life expectancy of a person born in 1932?
Q2: With reference to the value of the gradient, explain the meaning of the gradient in this context.
A2: 0.25. Life expectancy increases by 0.25 years (3 months) for each year later that a person is born.

Subject: MG2
Question: The area of a roof is 30 m\(^{2}\). Any rain that falls on the roof flows directly onto a garden.
Q1: Calculate how many litres of water flow onto the garden when 20 mm of rain falls on the roof.

Q1: Show that, at that time, approximately 3072 MB of data remained to be transferred.
Q2: Calculate the speed required to transfer 3072 MB in 7 minutes. Give your answer in megabits per second (Mbps), correct to the nearest whole number. (Note that 1 megabit = 1000000 bits.)

Q1: What is the area of the whole playground, correct to the nearest square metre?
